results.headline: Extraterrestrials Land at the O.K. Corral
results.summary_short: In “Cowboys & Aliens,” Daniel Craig rides into the New Mexico Territory and wrangles extraterrestrials that look like cousins of the monsters from the “Alien” films.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cowboys & Aliens

results.headline: Powerlifting as Escape
results.summary_short: In “All She Can” a young woman seeks a way out from her small Texas town through sports.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All She Can

results.headline: Best of All Possible Worlds: When Life Gives You Mud, Take a Mud Bath
results.summary_short: “The Optimists” consists of five vignettes, each of whose cynical stories of humble people embracing absurd illusions illustrate the universal impulse to believe in a better future, no matter what.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Optimisti

results.headline: Taste-Testing the Edge of Cuisine’s Envelope
results.summary_short: “El Bulli: Cooking in Progress” documents a year in the life of that famous Spanish restaurant and its visionary chef, Ferran Adrià.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Bulli: Cooking in Progress

results.headline: The Night Belongs to Teenage Yearning
results.summary_short: “The Myth of the American Sleepover” looks at the unsteady mixture of sophistication and naïveté that is central to modern American teenage life.
results.display_title: The Myth of the American Sleepover

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Myth of the American Sleepover

results.headline: A Cop Meets Bollywood
results.summary_short: “Singham” is about a super-tough village-born cop named Bajirao Singham, with bulging muscles and rock-hard morals.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Singham

results.headline: The Horror of Yesterday and the Everyday of Today
results.summary_short: “Sarah’s Key,” directed by Gilles Paquet-Brenner, is an adaptation of a best-selling novel by Tatiana De Rosnay, following a journalist’s investigation into a Holocaust tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sarah's Key

results.headline: It’s Just Sex. We’re Just Friends. You Know the Rules. Etc., Etc.
results.summary_short: Will Gluck’s “Friends With Benefits,” starring Mila Kunis and Justin Timberlake, is a romantic comedy about romantic comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friends with Benefits

results.headline: A Look at West Indies Cricket
results.summary_short: “Fire in Babylon” is a history of the West Indies’ dominance of international cricket in the 1970s and ’80s and the symbolic weight its teams carried in a post-colonial era.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fire In Babylon

results.headline: Hey, Brooklyn, Where’d You Get Those Muscles?
results.summary_short: “Captain America,” like its unapologetically corny hero, is propelled by unpretentious and plucky ingenuity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain America: The First Avenger

results.headline: Living in a Different World, Searching for a Second Chance
results.summary_short: A coming-of-age story with a science-fiction angle, “Another Earth” explores unspeakable grief.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Another Earth

results.headline: An Unsatisfying Life
results.summary_short: “A Little Help” stars Jenna Fischer as a Long Island dental hygienist whose life is deteriorating around her.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Help

results.headline: Diligently Turning Dostoyevsky German
results.summary_short: A documentary by Vadim Jendreyko about a translator and her eventful life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woman with the 5 Elephants

results.headline: Hundred Acre Gang Is Back in Town
results.summary_short: This “Winnie the Pooh” has no bells and whistles: it is comfortable with itself and confident in its ability to amuse and beguile young viewers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winnie the Pooh

results.headline: A Tree That Shelters Animal Life and Maybe Even a Dead Parent
results.summary_short: In “The Tree,” a Moreton Bay fig serves as title character and all-purpose metaphor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tree

results.headline: Was It Love? The ‘Manacled Mormon’ and His Kinky Weekend
results.summary_short: “Tabloid” revisits the case of the “Manacled Mormon,” which offered good, clean, dirty fun.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tabloid

results.headline: A Kidnap Thriller Cuts It Close
results.summary_short: “Daylight” is an unusually delicate psychological thriller and kidnap drama that favors suggestion over exposition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daylight

results.headline: A ‘Who Is It?’ More Than a Whodunit
results.summary_short: “The Chameleon” is based on the story of a French-born serial impostor and master of disguise who assumed scores of identities, especially those of missing teenagers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chameleon

results.headline: Ties That Bind: Life-Sustaining Friendships Transcending Life’s Brutalities
results.summary_short: “Snow Flower and the Secret Fan,” a movie based on the Lisa See book, explores foot binding and the relationships of two pairs of women during two periods of history.
results.display_title: Snow Flower and the Secret Fan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snow Flower and the Secret Fan

results.headline: An Evangelist, an Atheist and an Act That Tests Faith
results.summary_short: The accidental shooting of an atheist professor puts a former Deadhead turned man of faith at odds with his church.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salvation Boulevard
